report_title: Industry Research: Inland Water Transportation in the US
executive_summary: The industry primarily included companies engaged in providing waterborne transportation of cargo and passengers along the nation's lakes, rivers and other inland waterways. The industry has experienced varied conditions over the last few years. The COVID-19 pandemic, stagnant freight volumes, natural disasters and vast commodity price fluctuations all stifled industry growth. In addition, high competition from railroad and truck companies put downward pressure on industry freight rates, limiting revenue growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Competition from Railroad, Truck and Air Freight Companies is Strong
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Increasing competition from alternative modes of transportation has encouraged companies to expand their ship capacities to minimize operating expenses. Historically, the size of industry vessels has been limited by canal and port depth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue Growth Has Been Suppressed by Extreme Weather Conditions in 2018
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Between 2018 and 2019, heavy rainfalls along portions of the Mississippi River resulted in floods, becoming the longest-lasting flooding of the Mississippi River since 1927. Some companies had to reduce the number of barges in each tow and travel only a certain number of miles per day.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: As Cargo Volumes Exceed This Industry's Capacity, Increasing Government Funding Has Slightly Helped
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Even when dams and locks operate correctly, they often cannot handle longer barge chains, requiring barges to be split into two or more sections to fit through a dam or a lock. Increasing government funding and rising user fees have led to some decline in unscheduled lock closures in recent years, contributing to lower operating costs and fewer unscheduled delays.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: This Industry Will Continue to Recover From the Economic Effects of the COVID-19 Pandemic
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Industrial production and manufacturing activity will both expand in the coming years, increasing economic output for the transportation of raw materials, including sand and iron ore. Also, as crop production and exports grow, more grains will be shipped along the Mississippi River.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Competition from Pipelines and Rail Transportation Will Intensify
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Trains and an expanding pipeline network will present a significant threat to this industry. During the past five years, railroad companies have invested heavily in expanding capacity and infrastructure to capture a greater share of the freight transportation market.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consolidation Activity Will Also Rise in Lieu of Increasing Competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Price competition will remain strong, placing downward pressure on industry profit, especially on smaller companies. Large companies will continue consolidating, leading to higher operating efficiencies.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Israeli-Hamas War Sparks Instability in the Region, Shaking Up Shipping Routes from the East
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: After the onset of this conflict, the region began to slip into instability. Consequently, Houthi Rebels in Yemen began targeting shipping vessels passing through the Bab al-Mandab Strait to get to the Suez Canal and into the West. The drone and missile strikes from Houthi Rebels have forced ships from the East into longer routes around the tip of Africa.

industry_definition: This industry includes establishments primarily engaged in providing waterborne transportation of cargo and passengers along the nation's lakes, rivers and other inland waterways.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Industrial production index

key_trends: Internal competition is based on price, flexibility, speed, available services and equipment availability. Competition is most intense within the industry's barging segment.
External competition from railroads, trucks, planes and pipelines is intense even though waterborne transportation is often more environmentally friendly and efficient.
Competition from railroad, truck and air freight companies is strong. This competition has encouraged companies to expand their shipping capacities to minimize operating expenses.
Consolidation activity will rise in lieu of increasing competition. Larger companies will seek higher operating efficiencies.
This industry is dominated by small companies. These small companies account for more than 59.0% of the market share.
Ingram Barge Company and American Commercial Barge Line have the highest market share. Their combined market share is over 29.0%.

The federal government maintains exclusive jurisdiction over the navigable water of the United States. This authority is primarily delegated to the US Coast Guard and the US Army Corps of Engineers. The Bureau of Customs and Border Protection and the Transportation Security Administration also play an essential role in regulating this industry.
The Jones Act provides a monopoly for US coastal carriers since it requires all goods or passengers moved by water among US ports to be carried in US-built and US-flagged vessels.
Purchases are the most significant expense. Purchases include new or used vessels, fuel, barges and cranes and other cargo-handling equipment.
Wage costs skyrocketed as soon as pandemic-related closures and disruptions faded. These costs are still high compared with pre-pandemic years, but they will stabilize in the coming years.
The Southeast region is home to major transportation routes for cargo. No wonder this region has the most industry establishments.
The West is home to three out of the five largest container ports in the United States. This region also has several natural resources that attract water transportation companies.
Liquid bulk transportation has faced increasing competition from oil pipeline transporters. Liquid bulk transportation typically has higher economies of scale that enable them to charge lower prices.
There is an incentive for iron and construction industries to use inland water transportation since most of the iron ore is located near one of the Great Lakes.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Crops, especially wheat, soybeans and corn, are transported from major farming regions to Gulf Coast ports for export primarily using the Mississippi River System.

Coal-related industries include coal mining and coal-based power plants. Coal is typically transported along rivers to power plants and is used as an input to produce electricity. It is also moved along inland waterways to US ports for export.

Many companies transport petroleum or gas to and from refineries near the Gulf Coast. This process either involves carrying oil and gas imports from ports to inland refineries or transporting refined petroleum products from inland refineries to other areas of the United States for domestic consumption or trade.

The production of iron ore involves many processing activities that result in a multistep process of transporting iron ore from and to different processing facilities. Since most of the iron ore is located near one of the Great Lakes, there is a great incentive to use inland water transportation over other modes of transportation.

market_segmentation.segment: Consumer goods, consumers and other markets
market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment includes consumer goods manufacturers that range from electronics to toys, as well as auto and industrial equipment manufacturers. Out of all the industry's markets, this segment typically requires the transportation of the most value-added goods. No wonder revenue generated from this market greatly exceeds the tonnage moved on its behalf.

products_and_services.product_description: The transportation of dry bulk commodities includes basic materials that are often used to manufacture consumer goods, construct steel and building materials and generate electricity.

This segment is primarily dedicated to helping commercial vessels safely traverse harbors, rivers and other confined waterways where familiarity with local water depths, tides and potential hazards are of prime importance.

Liquid bulk transportation has faced increasing competition from oil pipeline transporters that typically have higher economies of scale that enable them to charge lower prices for oil and gas transportation.

Passenger transportation includes many classes of vessels used to provide inland water transportation of passengers on lakes rivers or Intracoastal waterways. Common passenger ships include ferries, cruise ships, water shuttles and water taxis.

Other transportation services provided by this industry include the transportation of automobiles, climate-controlled freight, waste and other specialized cargo. Major companies have increasingly offered value-added services in recent years to gain market share.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Oil, gas and derivative products are some of the industry's key sources of freight. When US oil and gas production increases, more of these commodities need to be transported by industry players for domestic and international use.

business_locations.location_description: The region is home to the Mississippi River, the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway and the Gulf Intracoastal Waterway. These are all major transportation routes for cargo including coal, agriculture products and petrochemical. This region also includes Florida which is home to the Port of Jacksonville, an important trade center with access to inland waterways as well as a substantial leisure boat and cruise industry.

New York has the highest number of establishments within the region. The region is also home to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the largest port complex on the East Coast, as well as the Hudson River-New York State Barge Canal system.

Similar to the Southeast region, the West region is home to several major cities with extensive port operations, including three out of the five largest container ports in the United States: Los Angeles, Long Beach and Oakland. This region also has natural resources, including timber, minerals and agricultural products. The transportation of these resources by water is essential for the regional economy.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The federal government maintains exclusive jurisdiction over the navigable water of the United States, including the nation's inland waterways. As a result, the industry is subject to regulation from the United States Coast Guard, the Maritime Administration, the Army Corps of Engineers, the Department of Transportation and the Department of Homeland Security, in addition to other federal and state government bodies.

The Federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972 (as amended by the Clean Water Act of 1977), the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act of 1981 and the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 (OPA) impose strict prohibitions against the discharge of oil and its derivatives or hazardous substances into the navigable waters of the United States. These acts impose civil and criminal penalties for any prohibited discharge and outline liability for cleanup of these discharges and any associated damages. Certain states also maintain water pollution laws that prohibit discharges into waters that traverse the state or adjoin the state.

In response to CDC guidance, various levels of regulation were implemented in the United States to discourage public gathering and large events due to the COVID-19 pandemic. In January 2021, CDC issued an order that required face masks to be worn by everyone while on public transportation, including all passengers and personnel operating conveyances, traveling within the United States.

barriers_points.barrier_description: One of the leading legal barriers is the requirement for companies to obtain a Coast Guard-issued license or permit to operate on navigable waters, a process that can be time-consuming and costly. Another barrier to entry is the Jones Act, which requires that all goods transported by water between US ports be carried on vessels that are built, owned and operated by US citizens.

Companies in this industry typically require a fleet of vessels, including barges and tugboats to operate. The costs of purchasing, leasing, insuring and maintaining these vessels can be substantial. Companies also need to obtain a Coast Guard-issued license or permit to operate on navigable waters, a process that can be time-consuming and costly. Significant capital investments are also required for the technology and support services that go along with operations.
The resources and market power of the industry's larger companies enable them to offer customers multiyear contracts, which locks out new entrants.

New entrants must maintain large, costly workforces to compete with established companies. As the number of qualified workers and marine personnel has declined in recent years because of the long hours and strenuous working conditions, new entrants must spend heavily on employee amenities, benefits and training and development programs.

factors_increased_barrier: Competition level is high and increasing
factors_decreased_barrier: Globalization level is low and steady

basis_points.basis_title: Internal competition based on price, flexibility, speed, services and equipment availability
basis_points.basis_description: Internal competition is based on price, flexibility, speed, available services and equipment availability. Competition is most intense within the industry's barging segment.

basis_points.basis_title: External competition from railroads, trucks, planes and pipelines
basis_points.basis_description: External competition from railroads, trucks, planes and pipelines is intense even though waterborne transportation is often more environmentally friendly and efficient.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 3 companies account for nearly half of industry revenue
concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry's three largest companies account for nearly half of the industry's total revenue.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Fragmented market dominated by small establishments
concentration_points.concentration_description: The other half of the market share is mainly fragmented and is dominated by establishments that employ fewer than five workers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Most companies are small sole proprietorships
concentration_points.concentration_description: No wonder the vast majority of companies are sole proprietorships that operate just one boat (often part-time) for passenger travel, specialized cargo transportation or subcontracting to larger companies.

concentration_points.concentration_title: High capital costs limit expansion for small companies
concentration_points.concentration_description: High capital costs make it difficult for small companies to expand.
Consolidation activity will stay high as larger companies look to expand.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Some Companies Choose to Lease Vessels and Equipment to Reduce Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases represent a significant expense. Purchases include new or used vessels, fuel, barges and cranes and other cargo-handling equipment. Since these costs are relatively large, this industry is vulnerable to fluctuations in the price of materials, supplies and commodities. Rising oil cost volatility during the period is expected to have pushed more operators toward renting rather than owning, giving them more control over operations.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wage Costs Shot Up in Line with Post-COVID-19 Demand
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: This industry is relatively labor-intensive, with workers needed to handle freight and operate barges, tugboats and ships. The crews employed in this industry include captains, pilots, engineers, tanker men and ordinary seamen.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: New entrants must maintain large, costly workforces to compete with established companies. As the number of qualified workers and marine personnel has declined in recent years because of the long hours and strenuous working conditions, new entrants must spend heavily on employee amenities, benefits and training and development programs.

Innovation in this industry is focused on increasing efficiency, emission and safety. Innovation trends include using fuel-efficient vessels, implementing technology for monitoring and reducing emissions and developing new navigation and communication systems to improve safety.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The COVID-19 pandemic had damning effects on revenue
volatility_points.volatility_description: Many businesses in this industry experienced reduced demand for their services due to travel restrictions and quarantine measures implemented in response to the pandemic. These measures also reduced demand for goods and materials that are typically transported by inland waterways, further reducing demand for transportation services. The disrupted supply chains further made it more difficult for businesses to obtain the resources they need to operate.

volatility_points.volatility_title: A variety of economic indicators influence revenue
volatility_points.volatility_description: Strong economic conditions stimulate industrial activity which in turn increases demand for water transportation services. High fuel prices can increase the cost of operating water transportation vehicles, which can reduce revenue. Government regulations and policies can also increase revenue volatility as stricter environmental regulations mean companies may have to invest in new technologies or equipment to meet those requirements.

volatility_points.volatility_title: OVERSUPPLY OF CARGO CARRYING CAPACITY REDUCES PROFIT
volatility_points.volatility_description: As a result of the length of time required to order and build a ship, the industry tends to either overshoot or undershoot on its demand forecasts for its fleet, casing supply and demand imbalances. An oversupply of cargo carrying capacity can lead to increased competition and lower prices as companies race to fill their flits.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Innovation in this industry is focused on increasing efficiency, emission and safety. Innovation trends include using fuel-efficient vessels, implementing technology for monitoring and reducing emissions and developing new navigation and communication systems to improve safety.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or produce a diversified range of services?
FAQs.answer: Operators often tailor their barges or location to cater to specific commodity/freight markets, such as oil, agriculture or coal. A diverse range helps maintain revenue during supply or price shocks.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the change in total trade value?
FAQs.answer: Total trade is significant to a number of operators who carry commodities to ports and harbors for export, or carry imports along to factories and distribution centers.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile crude oil prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Crude oil represents both a major industry product and a major cost input. Therefore, changes in oil prices may affect both profit and transportation volumes.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in locations with well-established infrastructure networks?
FAQs.answer: The Mississippi River is the primary location of industry operators due to key locations along the gulf and up through the states, with the waterways even connecting to the Great Lakes.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology, such as data analysis software and GPS, to establish a competitive edge over your competitor
FAQs.answer: Technology systems are crucial for managing freight capacity and delivering freight on time, as well as potentially providing value-added products to customers who can track and manage cargo during transportation.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Wages have historically accounted for 20-25% of total industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Have you had any regulatory expenses that have significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Regulation of emissions and also safety have affected operators in a number of ways. Mandatory double-hulling, for example, has created an added cost for all operators tasked with upgrading their fuel-carriers.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Unionization isn't common among workers, but access to trade organizations and other industry-aid groups can benefit operators looking to gain market share and stay ahead of industry trends.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Large industry operators tend to generate higher profit due to economies of scale and better contract terms.

FAQs.question: What challenges does your company face financing its ongoing operations?
FAQs.answer: The high cost of capital is a significant barrier to entry in the industry, which makes access to capital and secure financing a key component of operation.

FAQs.question: What percent of your vessels is fully utilized annually? How do you maximize capacity utilization?
FAQs.answer: Capacity utilization typically varies between 85% and 95% under normal conditions. Since operators only profit when barges are full, performing under capacity can have negative effects on bottom-line performance.

FAQs.question: How often does your company alter its prices? Do you use fuel volatility clauses in your pricing contracts?
FAQs.answer: Since fuel is a major industry input, changes in oil prices can take quite a toll on the industry, therefore operators must ensure their pricing and surcharge schemes are dynamic.

FAQs.question: How does your company keep up with environmental regulations? Are you flexible to accommodate new or updated requirements?
FAQs.answer: Operators in the Inland Water Transportation industry are considered more environmentally friendly than trucks and trains, by CO2 emissions. Growing encroachment by the EPA will continue to be both a problem and an opportunity for charter flight operators.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your revenue is derived from fuel surcharges? How do you plan for volatile fuel prices?
FAQs.answer: Fuel expenses account for a large portion of industry costs. These prices are often volatile due to environmental, economic and geopolitical factors. However, higher fuel prices can generally be passed on to customers through fuel surcharges.

FAQs.question: How closely does your company monitor trends in industrial production? How do you take advantage of an increase in the industrial production index?
FAQs.answer: When industrial activity climbs, the need for domestic and international transportation of goods, materials and commodities increases, leading to greater demand for inland water transportation services.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your cargo comprises petrochemicals? How do you plan to capitalize on an increase in the oil and gas production index?
FAQs.answer: When US oil and gas production increases, more of these commodities need to be transported by industry players for domestic and international use.
